text: A PLANE falling two stories per second. This is real... CUT TO BLACKOUT.
Mayday, Mayday, this is Cactus 1549! Lost both engines. Both engines. BLACK WHIPS INTO...

CAPTAIN “SULLY” SULLENBERGER, 57, lithe, intense, is behind the stick of this plummeting plane. ALARMS are sounding. CACOPHONY. VERTIGO. Beside Sully, First Officer -- JEFF SKILES, 49, youthful, handsome. Skiles is desperately trying to get the engines started again.
No re-light. On one or two. CUT TO BLACKOUT.
The SCREEN QUIVERS and hums. All we hear is... (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 2.
Cactus 1549, you can land on runway one-three, if you want it, it’s yours.
‘Pull up, pull up. Terrain. Pull up.’ BLACK INCINERATES TO...
FIRE. Both engines howling and useless.
‘Terrain, terrain, pull up, pull up.’
Departure control, we can make it back. We’re returning to LaGuardia.
No relight. We got no power. CUT TO BLACKOUT.
The sound of the ALARMS wail on. The rip of the falling plane through the pitiless air.
The ALTIMETER pins toward 0. Out the windshield, only -- WATER, 360.
(into radio) LaGuardia Tower, 1549. Trying to make 1-3.
We're too low. (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 3.
‘Terrain. Pull up. Pull up.’ CUT TO BLACKOUT.
The SCREEN RATTLES and SHORTS IN and OUT.
Come on, just a little further, goddamn it.
The Manhattan skyline appears, nearly filling the plane's windscreen.
PASSENGERS scream and panic. The hellish wait for IMPACT.
Lorrie. I love you. CUT TO BLACKOUT.
Silence. Long silence. CRASH. The -- SOUND of the plane smashing into a high-rise apartment building.
The plane... shears the fourth floor in half. The skin- crawling screech of metal on concrete on bone. EXPLOSION, as the engines catch fire and the plane careens down the city street... (CONTINUED)
10 11 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 4.
Taxis, pedestrians, all vanquished by the hurricane of violence. BOOM. The plane -- EXPLODES. And spreads its damage as it burns. The SCREEN FILLS WITH panic and fire and death.
A MAN IN SILHOUETTE sits up, his breath banging out of him. CLOSE ON MAN’S FACE Sully. Breathing. Haunted.

EXT. EAST RIVER BIKE PATH -— DAWN 11 We are ON the BACK OF Sully’s head, as he runs fast and hard along the East River. Then AROUND TO Sully’s face, his eyes dark with focus and the shadow of the nightmare he is trying to shed. He wears an all-black sweatsuit, and despite the harsh cold, sweat pours down his expressionless face. Not many out so early on a winter’s dawn. Sully has the pathway mostly to himself. And as he runs... he cannot elude the relentless sounds and images of his nightmare. Out of nowhere... SCREECH and HORN of a CAR as Sully just avoids getting clipped by a passing car. Sully just keeps running... west now, back into the teeth of the city. Unable to get enough speed to elude his own thoughts.
12 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 5.

Silence. Just the hum of a hotel room as Sully slowly dresses in his white shirt, (no epaulets), and black pants. Every motion he makes is precise, but a beat slow. And it is too quiet in here. So he remotes on the TV. Every channel he checks is focused on the flight 1549 MIRACLE ON THE HUDSON. Shots of the PLANE IN THE WATER, PASSENGERS on the wings and in the emergency rafts. Ecstatic SURVIVORS hugging on the docks. Surviving passenger BARRY LEONARD, 50, handsome and amazed, is shivering with cold and joy while being interviewed by a TV reporter.

(Southern accent) When I looked out the window and saw he was going to land us in the river... I thought... it’s over. What else could I think? Another channel. Another interview. DIANE HIGGINS, 58, lovely and stunned, is in blissful shock.
You think you’re going to die, that’s what you think. And then... miraculously... you don’t. Channel change. Back to Barry.
(into camera) ... I guess I could only say thank you... thank you for saving my life. Sully watches the television and it feels like a show more than the news. Is this his life?
Thank you, Captain. (choking up) Thank you. Thank... (CONTINUED)
12 13 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 6.
He smooths out the lines in his shirt, looks in the mirror. But somehow can’t quite meet his own gaze. As we PUSH DEEP INTO Sully’s eyes, we hear...
(pre-lap) «+. you. Yes, thank you, Captain Sullenberger, for joining us today...

Sully and Skiles are sitting in a halogen-bright room, with two glasses of water in front of them. Next to them is MIKE CLEARY, their union rep. He’s 50s, black hair, intense bearing. Across the table from them are the 3 NTSB members. ELIZABETH DAVIS, late 40s, gentle face, BEN EDWARDS, 50s, a banker’s demeanor and focus, and CHARLES PORTER, mid- 40s, Marine-tough, who is beginning the session.
«+. and welcome also to First Officer Skiles. Glad you could make it in this morning.
Not as glad as we are. Slight laughter.

For the record, we have an Aircraft Systems Team on this investigation, also Aircraft Structures, MRT, Aircraft Performance, ATC, Wildlife Factors, Survival Factors, and Emergency Response. Today, we begin with our Operations and Human Performance investigation, of the crash of U.S. Air Flight 1549.
Water landing.
Captain? (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 7.
This was not a crash. It was not a ditching. We knew what we were executing. A forced water landing.
Why didn’t you attempt to return to LaGuardia?
There was simply not enough altitude. The river was the only place long enough, wide enough, and smooth enough to even attempt to land the airplane safely.
Air Traffic testified that you stated you were returning to LaGuardia. But you didn’t.
As I began the left turn, I realized I couldn’t make it back. It would have ruled out all other options. Returning would have been a mistake.
Let’s get into how you calculated all those parameters.
There wasn’t time for calculating. I had to rely on my experience of managing the altitude and speed on thousands of flights, over four decades.
You're saying you...
Eyeballed it.
You eyeballed it?
The best chance those passengers had was on that river. I'd bet my life on it. In fact, I did. And I would do it again. (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 8.
Aviation engineers are theorizing that you had enough energy to make it back to a runway.
Engineers are not pilots. They’re wrong. And they weren’t there.
Regardless, we have to follow up all implications as part of our investigation.
Our computers will run return scenario algorithms to generate simulations with your exact parameters. The dual engine loss, the altitude. Everything you faced when you made your decision.
I'd like to oversee those computer simulations.
Not possible during an investigation.
You stated it was a dual engine failure due to multiple bird- strikes.
That would be unprecedented.

Everything is unprecedented. Until it happens the first time. The tension escalates. Mike Cleary shoots Sully a look to calm him down. But -- Sully digs in as the questions continue to come in an overlapping blur.
How much sleep did you get the night before?
8 hours. Enough. (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 9.
Is it possible your blood sugar was low?
I was rested. Completely aware of my surroundings.
When was your last drink, Captain Sullenberger?
A week ago.
Drugs?
No. Never.
First Officer Skiles?
Don’t drink. Never have.
Captain. How about any troubles at home? A beat.
No more than anyone else. And nothing that affected my work.
Darkness. It’s only 5 PM, but night presses in through the windows of the car driving Sully and Skiles and Cleary. In the backseat, Sully looks exhausted. Skiles sits in the front seat, fuming.
Why are they looking for something we did wrong, when it all turned out right? It’s bullshit. (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 10.
It didn’t turn out all right for the airline and their insurance company. We should expect some blowback.
Come on, Mike. What are they going to say, that he shouldn’t have saved everybody?
It’s not personal, the NTSB is doing their job. Once they have all the facts, it’1l calm down.

They should just pin on the medal and send you back to work. Sully doesn’t answer. Instead, he starts to dial his cell SULLY’S PHONE (V.O.) ‘The voice mailbox of Lorrie Sullenberger is full and cannot receive further messages.’
I didn’t call her since this morning. But apparently everyone else did.
A handsome Egyptian man in his early 50s. He takes the silence as a chance to speak.
Not meaning to bother, but I have to say, it is an honor driving you today.
Thank you.

What has it been this year so far? Bernie Madoff, the two wars without end, many million new people with no work... And that is just the first two weeks of January. (beat) Friday's headline? This is beautiful. (CONTINUED)
Driver holds up the Jan. 16th DAILY NEWS. Its headline reads... “HERO ON THE HUDSON.” With Sully’s photo inset.
Hey, Mike. How about we add the driver as a character witness? The car stops as it awaits its chance to turn into the hotel entrance. Traffic keeps them at bay for the moment.
A pack of paparazzi is waiting. INT. CAR —- CONTINUOUS ACTION 16 Sully sees the press and looks away. Then he pulls out his cell phone. Trying Lorrie one more time. It rings and rings and rings.
LORRIE SULLENBERGER, 50, fit, pretty, is in the backyard. She answers her cell.
Finally.
The NTSB had us tied up all day.
I just wanted to hear your voice on the phone. Been hearing everyone else’s. You'd be amazed at how many ‘cousins’ you have.

Driver finally makes the turn and stops outside the hotel. Cameras press up against the window, strobing Sully like a night at Studio 54. A BELLMAN opens the back door of the Town Car and the rush of noise is deafening. Sully has to yank it shut again to hear Lorrie. (CONTINUED)
Doesn't feel like family here.

CRANE UP FROM the b.g. to reveal their little street is clotted with worldwide media. Two dozen NEWS TRUCKS. PARABOLIC MICS, hordes of PHOTOJOURNALISTS. The doorbell rings, the home phone rings, news trucks honk as they crowd the tiny street.
Pretty quiet here, too. Sully’s door gets opened again. Mayhem in the streets. Chants of “Sully... Sully... Sully.”
The reporters want me to give an update. Inside the mind of Sully. What should I tell them?
Just tell them...
I can’t hear you. Call me back without the cheerleaders.
I was saying to tell...
I can’t hear you. Call. Me. Back. Lorrie hangs up.

Sully gets out of the car with Skiles exiting the other side. And like Michael Jordan and the rest of the Bulls, the press try to swarm Sully, and let Skiles slip through almost imperceptibly. Skiles waves amiably to Sully, happy to avoid the crush. And Sully is left behind, encircled by COPS keeping the tangle of cameras, arms, and microphones fifteen feet back. (CONTINUED)
The REPORTERS shout their questions.
How does it feel to be a miracle maker?
Show us your cape, Super Sully!

How did you pull off the impossible? TIME SLOWS. Each FLASHBULB like a blow to a boxer’s head. Sully winces, blinks, and finally closes his eyes. His anonymity is gone. Forever. And maybe more than that.

The shower burns. The bathroom is so full of steam that visibility is almost gone. The tub is running hot water and so is the sink. Sully has stuffed towels under the door to maximize the steam effect. Finally, amidst the murk, we see Sully sitting on the edge of the tub, with a wet towel over his head.
We see he is taking long, deep breaths. Trying to slow down his heart, which is still beating at double its regular rate. It’s not working.

The water is all stopped now, though steam lingers. Sully wipes the mirror to see his reflection and it comes back diffuse. Unclear in all the heat. And then the -- NOISE. The unmistakable roar of a PLANE plummeting to the ground. Deafening. He feels the sound crashing towards him, louder and louder. And louder. As Sully hurries in to escape the sound, he finds... (CONTINUED)
SILENCE. The sound is gone. Only the slow ticking of the bedside clock. And the fast ticking of his own troubled heart. Everything feels unsafe. Even the ground beneath his feet.

The SILHOUETTES of several photographers and reporters shadow the front window as -- Lorrie crosses in front, dialing the home phone. She walks downstairs as she waits. After several rings, it’s picked up.
I’m thinking about running over the press with the car. Self- defense. Think a jury would convict?
Sully, in a robe, with a beer in hand, is on the line.
Yes. Okay. Good.
I’m taking that as permission. The cops will be coming after you.
Whenever you're ready.
Sully. Are you even listening to me?
Is there a strange buzz on this line? Do you hear a buzz? Maybe we should talk later.
Honey. I’ve been waiting all day. This is later. Are you okay? (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 15.
Of course. Tired. That’s it. (beat) How are the girls?
They're... a little overwhelmed. (beat) Sounds like you are, too.
They'll be all right. It’s a lot. The sound of a photographer’s camera clinking against the kitchen window as the photographer comes too close.
Yes, it is. Lorrie draws the kitchen curtains, then remotes-on the kitchen TV. PULL BACK to reveal Lorrie has muted it.
The whole world’s talking about you. My Sully. I still can’t believe it. No answer.
They need me here longer. For the NTSB investigation. Did I tell you that already?
Sully, what is it?
Just tired. I apologize if I didn’t tell you.
You don’t have to apologize. You’re where you need to be.
I just want you to know. I did the best I could.
Of course you did. You saved everyone. (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 16.
Maybe we can talk tomorrow. The fatigue is... it feels like someone is inside my skin, sitting on my bones.
Do you want me to come be with you?
Thank you, Lorrie. But the girls... need you there. (beat) Tell them I love them, okay?
I love you. Get some sleep.

Yeah. And maybe when I wake up, it will be January 14th. That would be nice. They hang up. Both standing still. 3,000 miles of distance between them. And somehow, even further apart. DISSOLVE TO BLACK.
(pre-lap) Why Captain Sullenberger made that fateful decision to turn the Hudson River into a runway, only he can answer... but we now know that it was the wrong choice...
Sully’s in his sweats. “CBS News” is on, the volume peaked, replaying endless clips of the Miracle on the Hudson. On TV, KATIE COURIC stands by the Hudson River.
«+. A choice that endangered the lives of all on board. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
25 26 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 17.

And while much of the country hails him as a hero, this new information will certainly change everyone's understanding of the so- called ‘Miracle on the Hudson.’ Sometimes fireworks only exist to disguise fraud. From the banks of the Hudson, I’m Katie Couric. CBS News. Sully jerks AWAKE. He’s lying down in the hotel room. But the TV has been OFF the entire time. In fact, it’s UNPLUGGED. He rubs his face, wishing he could get his hands inside his skull to silence his brain. The clock reads 12:41 AM. He picks up his phone several times. Half dials Lorrie. Quits. Finally picks up the hotel phone and dials an extension. Two rings until... INT. JEFF SKILES’ HOTEL ROOM - SAME TIME 26 Skiles is sitting in a chair next to his made bed, drinking a soda, eating a mini-bar Snickers. He grabs the ringing phone.
Hello?
Jeff. Sorry to call this late.
It’s okay. No sleep in this room, either. Can you believe they charge five dollars for a Snickers? I could bankrupt the airline in about four bites.
Just wanted to see if... maybe you wanted...
.».. to talk? Absolutely. Let’s grab some air...  27 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 18.

The wind-whipped streets are empty and the closed storefronts and window displays make the street feel even emptier. The night is mean with cold and Sully and Skiles walk north on 5th Avenue, bundled up. Words don’t come easy.
You enjoying the shakes, the nightmares, and the rabbit heartbeat?
A little bit. (beat) The union offered us counseling...
What are they going to say? You were in a plane crash. And lived. It may have a minor impact on your day-to-day.
I just... hate not being able to control this process. I want myself back.
I’m hoping that six months from now, we’ll just be laughing about how we got to meet David Letterman.
We're doing ‘Letterman’?
Right after the NTSB interview. I’m guessing Dave will be funnier.
It’s all so surreal. I guess I’m just having a little trouble separating reality from... whatever the hell this is.
This... is two men freezing their asses off. (CONTINUED)
27 28 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 19.
They laugh, the steam from their mouths like unspoken thoughts.
Sully... don’t worry. You dida great thing and it’s going to be remembered for a very long time.
Funny thing is... I’ve delivered a million passengers, over 40 years in the air... and in the end I’1l be judged on 208 seconds.
Come on. Tomorrow's going to be a good day. Computer SIMS will prove you were right and we can all put our wings back on.
You're right. You're right. All back to normal. EXTREME CLOSEUP - SULLY’S EYES The street lights reflecting, as we...
ANOTHER EXTREME CLOSEUP - SULLY’S EYES 28 Lights still reflecting, but these are TV lights. PULL BACK to reveal he is sitting across from...
KATIE COURIC and her camera crew.
... it was obvious this was a critical situation... losing thrust in both engines, at a low altitude... over one of the most densely populated areas on the planet...
But choosing to land on the Hudson... there was still a big if... (CONTINUED)
28 29 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 20.
I was sure I could do it.
You were?
Yes.
How do you feel about people calling you a hero?
I don’t feel like a hero. I was just a man doing his job.
The right man for the job, at the right time. You’ve been flying for nearly 40 years.
42. It has been my life. My whole life. Sully’s eyes spark bright for a moment as we -- ZOOM INTO them and COME BACK OUT THROUGH --

Seeing all of Denison, Texas stretched out below him. Sixteen-year-old Sully sits in the front of this tandem two-seater prop plane. In the backseat is L.T. COOK, 50s, clean-shaven and gruff, but aware he’s witnessing the birth of a pilot.
Your aircraft. In the roar of the tiny cockpit, L.T. Cook circles the stick to signal it’s Sully’s plane, then takes his hands off the override controls. Sully circles his stick back in response.
(amazed) My aircraft. Sully flies. He dips low over the verdant Texas landscape. Low enough for his parents -- (CONTINUED)
29 30 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 21.
CHESLEY and PAULINE Sullenberger to wave up at him, proudly. He soars back up against the perfect blue and he looks absolutely in control. And free. Looks like he never wants to come down.

Sully lands the plane on his own. When the wheels touch down, it’s as if Sully’s memorizing the feel. The thrill. He was up there. Now he’s down here. He did it. Him. He and L.T. disembark and stand on the grass strip as the propeller does its final spin.
I‘’1l be busy crop dusting in the Super Cub the rest of the summer. So you can take the plane up, I guess. When you please. Sully doesn’t say anything.
Still six bucks an hour. I’11 consider it lesson time. A pilot never stops acquiring knowledge. You’1l make mistakes, everyone does. Just learn from them.
Yes, sir.
And never forget, no matter what’s happening, to fly the airplane.
Absolutely, sir.
One other thing. And this is important.
Yes, sir?
You can go ahead and smile. Sully’s face unleashes a deeply satisfied smile.  31 32 33 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 22.
Sully flies alone, trying out new maneuvers. Memorizing everything on the panels, constantly testing himself, improving. He banks into the blue, and when he returns to level, we are...
And this time his Mother is on board. PAULINE Sullenberger is 41 and attractive. She’s also relaxed, hands calmly on her lap, as if out for a Sunday drive.
Your stomach’s not queasy, Mom?
No.
Not too noisy for you?
No, now let’s enjoy. Just go low and slow. She reaches over and squeezes his shoulder.
You realize that if you’d studied piano like this, we’d be on our way to Carnegie Hall now.

This is my piano, Mom. (pause) And I can still get us to Carnegie Hall. They laugh and she squeezes his hand, beyond proud. PUSH IN CLOSE ON Sully’s joy-filled face, not a drop of sweat despite the Texas heat...
Sully’s face, now 57, and moist with sweat. The Katie Couric interview is over. Lights get switched off, camera packed up. Katie’s long gone, and -- (CONTINUED)
33 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 23.
ALISON, cute, mid-20s, is removing the rest of Sully’s foundation, but he can’t stop sweating.
Sorry about the perspiration.
After what you did, I’d think that Katie couldn’t be too intimidating.
Not Katie. The lights and camera she brought with her.
(beat) All done. Alison gets on tiptoes and kisses Sully’s cheek.
That was from my mom. Her name’s Brenda. She says to say thank you, and she’s single. They laugh.
Tell Brenda thanks, but I’ve got a girl at home.

Lucky woman. Alison exits and... Sully is alone. Waiting in this strange hotel room, amidst the silence of not knowing what is going to happen next... he feels like the last man on Earth. He stares out onto the streets of Midtown 30 floors below. Reflected in the window, we see the city before him. And then... A PLANE... plummeting towards the Manhattan skyline. SULLY’S POV As the jet descends relentlessly across the canyon of buildings, hidden by high-rises and then reappearing, like a ghost that won’t perish. (CONTINUED)
33 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 24.

Half the left wing severs free as it slams a building, then the plane vanishes again, behind a wall of skyscrapers. BOOM. The plane detonates out of view, fire and debris licking out and around, still visible... the explosion echoing through the streets.
Sully. Sully...

still gazing out the window. His eyes are vacant, his nightmare still shadowing him. But there is no reflection in the window. And outside, there is no plane in ruins. No fire. Just the city in motion.
Sully! Finally, Sully whiplashes back to find -- Mike Cleary, his union rep, standing by the door.
Sully, where are you? Sully looks out the window one last time. Nothing.
I’m standing here, calling your name... what’s up with you? Sully keeps staring out. Transfixed.

You need to get focused, because the media request avalanche continues. Larry Rooney volunteered to jump in and ride shotgun with you the rest of the way. Thought you might need a friend. He’ll take you to today’s NTSB meeting. (beat) Sully. Are you hearing me? Sully finally looks at Cleary. (CONTINUED)
33 34 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 25.
Airbus completed their computer simulations as well.
Good. Good. That will help.
There’s something else. Arnie Gentile called... he got the ACARS data. (beat) The left engine was still operating at idle. Sully feels like he’s been stabbed.
That’s not possible. I felt it go. It was like being stopped in mid-air.
Arnie said there was a chance it was sub-idle. That it still could’ve had thrust. Sully doesn’t answer.
Just thought you should know. Since the NTSB already does.

WOLF PACK OF PAPARAZZI at the hotel door, as -- Sully exits the hotel where the Katie Couric interview just took place. His eyes show an unfamiliar reticence, and he scans the crowd for a familiar face. He finds one in -- LARRY ROONEY. 47, stocky, friendly, intense. He wears a U.S. Air uniform, snugly over a slight paunch. Larry waves from beside the car and Sully slowly makes his way through the mayhem. Larry pulls him free of the final strangers, into a vehicle. (CONTINUED)
34 35 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 26.
Larry. Nice to finally see a friendly face. The Town Car’s dark windows turn the media throng into a horde of silhouettes.
Might be the last one you see today.
The tension is high as Sully and Skiles sit across from the investigators. Rooney is by their side for support. And -- Skiles is riled up.
Isn’t it a little early in the year to go fishing?
Seeking the facts is hardly fishing, Mr. Skiles.
Okay. Then here is the most important fact. There are only two people who know what happened in the cockpit that day, and I’m one of them.
And we appreciate your perspective...
Why do you think we’re even here today? It’s because Captain Sullenberger did not head back to LaGuardia. No response. (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 27.

Look, I just finished training on the A320, and I can tell you that the only reason the plane operated as well as it did, that the aircraft could land anywhere, is because Captain Sullenberger turned on the Auxiliary Power Unit.
He was simply following the QRH...
No. He wasn’t following the proper procedure at all. And I know, because I had the QRH in my hands. The board leans forward. Interested.
He switched on the APU immediately after engine roll back. According to Airbus, that’s the fifteenth thing on the list to do. Fifteenth. Silence.
If he’d followed the damn rules, we'd all be dead. (heating up) Maybe that’s the part you don’t like. You’re not used to having answers to your guesses.

(smoothing) Look, what Jeff is saying is that I know the A320. What it does and doesn’t do. I’ve read countless CVR transcripts of deceased pilots and I have significant accident investigation experience.
There is no question that you are an experienced, dedicated, talented professional. (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 28.
But all the flights you piloted before January 15th and every crash you investigated are not the purview of this investigation. Only U.S. Airways 1549 matters today. The room takes a breath.
Your union has been advised... ACARS data relayed that the left engine continued to turn throughout the flight.
Then the data would be wrong.
The evidence shows the left engine was at idle or sub-idle immediately following the bird strike.
(punched) Show me the left engine and it’1l be dead geese and no power.
The left engine was lost in the crash, due to the extensive damage on touchdown, but we’1ll circle back to that. Let’s assume it was, aS you say, a dual engine loss due to bird strike...
Your weight was 151,510 lbs. Wind and temperature, N-NW, 21 degrees. Speed and altitude, 200 knots at 2,818 feet. Agreed?
That’s correct.
We were able to run all the algorithms concurrently. (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 29.
And the resulting computer simulations of U.S. Airways Flight 1549 showed that the aviation engineers... were correct.
There was enough altitude and speed after the bird strike, for a successful return to LaGuardia.
(dubious) Successful?
The plane landed at LaGuardia. Intact. Undamaged.
You got that from one computer simulation?
No. From twenty.

Including attempts for Teterboro runway 19, and LaGuardia, runways 22 and 13. Every computer simulation, with the exact flight parameters, demonstrated that a return was possible. And not just possible. Probable. The room goes ghost quiet.
Does anyone need to hear further computer evidence? Silence.
Captain Sullenberger, First Officer Skiles?
(shaken) Not at this time.
No. (CONTINUED)
SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 30.
I would like to go over all the parameters used...
We’ll make them available to the union.
Thank you.

And once the investigation is complete, we’ll be able to share the actual computer simulations. For now, they remain confidential. We can’t afford a leak to the press. (beat) There’s been far too much talk in the press already. NTSB stands. The room is somber.

When the complete Cockpit Voice Recording is compiled, with ATC, and all on-board transcripts combined, we will call you back. The NTSB exits. So does Larry Rooney, who follows them out with hushed questions. Only Sully and Skiles remain. Sully looks stunned.
They're playing Pac-Man, you were flying a plane full of human beings.
Somehow. Not the way I remember it. It just doesn’t seem right.

Because it’s not right. Sully, you did everything you could. And it was more than enough. Ask the passengers. Ask your wife and kids. Ask mine. The two men stare straight ahead, dumbfounded by the turn of events. PUSH IN CLOSER. CLOSER...
36 SULLY - 11/18/15 (Full Blue) 31. INT. HOTEL ROOM - EXTREME CLOSEUP - SULLY AND SKILES’ 36
Because we are watching them on TV. Their expressions are now strained smiles, as they weather lighthearted questions from -- DAVID LETTERMAN.
